title: Core idea
content:
• Food is sealed in a heat-safe bag (vacuum or zip-top with air removed).
  • The bag is placed in a water bath held at a specific temperature using an immersion circulator.
  • Because the water and the food are at the same temperature, food cannot overcook in the same way it would in a pan or oven.
  • Time in the bath ensures that the center of the food reaches the target temperature and, where needed, that connective tissue softens.

After cooking in the bath, many foods are finished in a pan, on a grill, or under the broiler for color and texture.

title: Equipment
content:
Minimum setup:

  • Immersion circulator – the device that heats and circulates water.
  • Container – heat-safe pot or dedicated plastic tub.
  • Bags – vacuum bags or sturdy freezer-grade zip-top bags.
  • Weights or clips – to keep bags submerged and separated.

Helpful extras:

  • Probe thermometer – for sanity-checking internal temperature on thick cuts.
  • Cast-iron or heavy skillet – for searing.
  • Torch or grill – optional tools for finishing and adding color.

title: Bagging and sealing
content:
• Use vacuum bags or good-quality freezer bags. Thin, cheap bags can soften or leak at long times or higher temperatures.
  • Remove as much air as practical:
    • With a vacuum sealer, avoid “crushing” delicate foods (fish, burgers, some vegetables); use gentle or pulse settings.
    • With zip-top bags, use the water displacement method:
      • Lower the open bag slowly into the water, letting the water push air out.
      • Seal just before the zipper line reaches the water surface.
  • Keep the sealing area dry so the seal holds well.

For high-fat foods or long cooks, double-bagging can add peace of mind.

title: Keeping bags submerged
content:
Bags that float can cook unevenly.

  • Make sure there is enough water in the container.
  • Place a spoon, butter knife, or small weight inside the bag on the side opposite the meat.
  • Use racks or clips to keep multiple bags separated and fully under water.
  • Check occasionally on very long cooks (overnight and longer) and top up water as needed.

title: Temperatures, times, and safety
content:
Each recipe lists a bath temperature and a time range.

  • Thicker pieces (steaks, roasts) need more time for heat to reach the center.
  • Some cuts (shoulder, brisket, chuck, ribs) benefit from extended time even after reaching the target temperature, to convert collagen into gelatin and become tender.

As a general mindset:

  • For steaks and tender cuts, pick a doneness temperature (e.g., 54 °C / 129 °F for medium-rare) and cook long enough for even heating.
  • For tougher cuts, pick a texture goal (e.g., sliceable brisket vs. shreddable) and follow the longer time ranges given in each recipe.

Food safety:

  • Keep food refrigerated until it goes into the water bath.
  • Use the bath temperatures and times given in the recipes; they are chosen with typical safety guidance in mind.
  • When cooking in advance, chill food quickly after the bath (see “Make-ahead and chilling” below).

title: Searing and finishing
content:
Sous-vide gives perfect internal doneness, but most foods are better with a browned exterior.

Common finishing methods:

  • Pan-searing
    • Dry the surface very well with paper towels.
    • Heat a heavy pan until very hot.
    • Use a high smoke-point oil (e.g., canola, vegetable oil) and sear briefly on all sides.
    • Add butter and aromatics at the end for flavor; baste quickly.
  • Grilling or broiling
    • Ideal for steaks, chops, and some vegetables.
    • Pat food dry and oil lightly to prevent sticking.
    • Sear over high heat just long enough to develop color.
  • Torch finishing
    • Useful for small items or delicate surfaces.
    • Use in combination with a brief pan or grill sear when possible.

General rule: the hotter the finishing surface, the shorter the time you need.

Aim to build color without raising the internal temperature more than a few degrees.

title: Make-ahead and chilling
content:
One of the biggest advantages of sous-vide is the ability to cook in advance.

Basic pattern:

  1. Cook in the water bath as usual.
  2. If you are not serving right away, chill quickly:
    • Transfer the sealed bag to an ice bath (50% ice, 50% water) for 20–30 minutes, or until cool in the center.
  3. Move the chilled bag to the refrigerator.

Typical storage guidance (for home cooking):

  • Chilled sous-vide meats and fish: up to 2–3 days in the fridge.
  • Many vegetables: 3–5 days.

To serve later, reheat the sealed bag in a water bath a few degrees below the original cooking temperature until warmed through, then remove, dry, and finish as usual.

Recipes marked Make-ahead or Great for leftovers are especially well suited to this pattern.

title: Ultimate Steak
content:
Description: This method produces perfectly cooked, thick‑cut steaks with a uniform interior and a crisp exterior. A quick sear before and after the water bath enhances flavour and locks in juices. This entry combines the temperature/time comprehensive cooking tables with the complete ingredient list and preparation steps from later uploads.

Tags: Beginner-friendly · Weeknight-friendly · Guests · Low effort

Rare 52 °C
Medium‑rare (recommended) 54 °C
Medium 56 °C
Well‑done 60 °C

Ingredients

  • Double‑cut steak(s) (ribeye, strip or similar; thicker cuts sear and cook more evenly)
  • Salt and freshly ground black pepper
  • Olive oil
  • 1 garlic clove, lightly crushed
  • Fresh thyme sprigs
  • 1 fresh bay leaf
  • Butter (for the final sear)

Equipment

  • Sous‑vide circulator and water bath
  • Gallon‑sized ziplock-style bag or vacuum bag
  • Heavy skillet for searing
  • Trivet or heatproof pad

Method

  1. Choose and trim – Select a thick, double‑cut steak. Trim away any hard fat or silverskin so only tender meat remains.
  2. Season and pre‑sear – Season the steak generously with salt and pepper. Heat a skillet over high heat with a little olive oil and sear the steak for about 1 minute per side to develop colour and flavour. Transfer to a plate to cool slightly.
  3. Bag with aromatics – Place the cooled steak in a bag with the garlic clove, thyme sprigs, bay leaf and a drizzle of olive oil. Remove air via vacuum or the water‑displacement method.
  4. Cook sous‑vide – Preheat the water bath to the desired doneness temperature. Submerge the sealed steak and cook according to the time table above (fresh versus frozen thickness). Clip the bag to the side to keep it submerged. If it floats, tuck a spoon inside to act as a weight.
  5. Finish and serve – Remove steak from the bag and pat dry. Heat a skillet until smoking. Add butter and the bag’s aromatics. Sear the steak again for about 1 minute per side, basting with the foaming butter to build a crisp crust. Rest briefly, slice if desired, and enjoy.

title:
Indoor Barbecued Beef
Short Ribs Your Way
content:
Description: Sous‑vide beef short ribs cooked to your preferred texture—sliceable or shreddable—then glazed and briefly roasted. The cook time and temperature determine whether the meat is rosy and steak‑like or fall‑apart tender.

Tags: Weekend project · Great for leftovers · Make-ahead · Guests

Time & temperature options

Texture style Time Temperature
Steak‑like and sliceable 48 h 54 °C
Lusciously juicy (Joule favourite) 12 h 70 °C
More braisey, shreddable 24 h 75 °C
Pulled‑style, very tender 8 h 85 °C

Ingredients

  • 1 rack beef short ribs
  • Smoked salt or another salt of your choice
  • 1 jar barbecue sauce

Equipment

  • Sous‑vide circulator and water bath
  • Heavy‑duty sous‑vide bag (preferred) or double bagged ziplock‑style bags
  • Trivet or heatproof pad
  • Oven for the final glaze/roast

Method

  1. Trim – Trim away any thick, hard fat or tough silverskin. A cleaner rack yields better results, especially at lower temps.
  2. Season generously – Rub the ribs with smoked salt and coat thoroughly with barbecue sauce.
  3. Bag – Place ribs in a heavy‑duty sous‑vide bag. Remove air and seal.
  4. Cook – Preheat the water bath to your chosen temperature. Submerge the ribs and cook for the time shown in the table above. For long cooks, cover the pot to minimise evaporation (using a Flip Top lid or plastic wrap). Make sure the bag stays under water; weight it down if necessary.
  5. Reduce juices – After cooking, pour the bag juices into a saucepan and simmer until reduced to a sticky glaze.
  6. Glaze and roast – Coat the cooked ribs with the reduced glaze. Place in a 400 °F / 205 °C oven for about 10 minutes to dry the surface and set the glaze.
  7. Serve – Slice or shred as desired. Serve with extra barbecue sauce and your favourite sides.

title:
Korean‑Style Beef Short Ribs
(Kalbi)
content:
Description: Thick‑cut marinated Korean short ribs cooked sous‑vide, then grilled over high heat to develop a charred kalbi crust. Choose the time/temperature combination below to control tenderness.

Time & temperature

Temperature Time Result
65 °C 8 h Sliceable with some bite
70 °C 8 h Tender, balanced texture
75 °C (our favourite) 8 h Rich and braisey

Ingredients

  • Thick‑cut, marinated Korean‑style short ribs (about ½ lb / 225 g per serving)
  • Sesame seeds, for garnish
  • Chopped scallions, for garnish

Equipment

  • Sous‑vide circulator and water bath
  • Sous‑vide bag or ziplock‑style bag
  • Flip Top lid or high‑quality plastic wrap (to cover pot while cooking)
  • Trivet or heatproof pad
  • Super‑hot grill

Method

  1. Select & arrange – Use thick‑cut short ribs. Arrange them in the bag in flat, even layers.
  2. Seal – Vacuum seal or use the water‑displacement method.
  3. Cook – Preheat the water bath to your chosen temperature. Cook for 8 hours. Cover the pot to limit evaporation. Weight the bag if it floats.
  4. Grill – Preheat a grill until very hot. Remove ribs from the bag, pat dry and grill over high heat until well charred, about 5–10 minutes.
  5. Garnish & serve – Sprinkle with sesame seeds and chopped scallions. Serve with rice, kimchi and other banchan.

title: Flank Steak (Tender Slices for Fajitas or Bowls)
content:
Description: Flank steak can be chewy if cooked hot and fast. Sous-vide keeps it medium-rare and sliceable for salads, fajitas or rice bowls.

Tags: Beginner-friendly · Weeknight-friendly · Low effort · Great for leftovers

Ingredients

  • Flank steak (1 piece, ~1–1.5 in / 2.5–3.8 cm thick)
  • Salt
  • Freshly ground black pepper
  • 1–2 tbsp olive oil
  • Optional: 2–3 garlic cloves, smashed
  • Optional: fresh rosemary or thyme sprigs

Equipment

  • Sous-vide circulator and water bath
  • Vacuum bag or zip-top freezer bag
  • Heavy skillet or grill for finishing

Method

  1. Pat steak dry and season generously with salt and pepper; add garlic and herbs if using.
  2. Place steak and olive oil in the bag in a single layer; vacuum-seal or use the water-displacement method.
  3. Preheat water to 54 °C / 129 °F and cook according to thickness and state (see table).
  4. Optionally chill in an ice bath if preparing ahead, then refrigerate.
  5. Remove from bag, pat very dry, and sear in a very hot skillet or on a hot grill, 30–60 seconds per side, just to brown.
  6. Rest briefly, then slice very thinly against the grain for serving.

content:

content:
Description: Baby back ribs cooked sous‑vide and finished in a hot oven for a crunchy bark. Adjust the cook time/temperature to achieve your favourite texture.

Tags: Weekend project · Great for leftovers · Make-ahead · Guests

Time Temperature Result

Ingredients

  • 1 rack baby back ribs
  • Salt
  • Dry rub of your choice
  • Glaze of your choice

Equipment

  • Sous‑vide circulator and water bath
  • Vacuum sealer and bag
  • Oven for finishing

Method

  1. Trim – Remove the tough membrane from the bone side of the ribs.
  2. Salt and portion – Lightly salt the rack and cut in half if needed so it fits flat in the bag.
  3. Bag and cook – Arrange ribs in the bag in a flat layer and seal. Preheat water to the chosen temperature and cook for the selected time. Keep the bag submerged; weigh it down if it floats.
  4. Glaze and rub – After cooking, brush ribs with your glaze and sprinkle on the dry rub.
  5. Crisp in the oven – Transfer ribs to a 400 °F / 205 °C oven for about 10 minutes to develop a crunchy bark.
  6. Serve – Slice between the bones and serve with additional glaze or sauce.

Description: Only the neck portion of the squash is used so the pieces cook evenly. Finished with optional garnishes such as Parmesan, sage leaves or pumpkin seed pesto.

Tags: Beginner-friendly · Weeknight-friendly · Great for leftovers · Make-ahead

Ingredients

For the squash

  • 1 medium butternut squash (neck only)
  • Salt – about 1 tbsp
  • Olive oil – 2–3 tbsp

Optional garnishes (per 4 servings)

  • 4 thin slices Parmesan per serving
  • Pumpkin seed oil – a few drizzles per serving
  • Pan‑fried sage leaves – about 5 leaves per serving
  • Pumpkin seed pesto – about 3 tbsp per serving
  • Salt and black pepper to taste

  • Sous‑vide circulator and water bath

  5. Seal – Vacuum seal.
  6. Protect – Use a trivet under the bath container.
  7. Cook – Cook at 90 °C for 30 minutes.
  8. Serve – Eat plain or top with any combination of Parmesan, sage, pumpkin seed oil or pesto.

Tags: Beginner-friendly · Weeknight-friendly · Low effort · Kids-friendly

Ingredients

For the optional garlic oil

  • 3–4 garlic cloves, peeled
  • About 0.25 cup (60 ml) olive oil
  • 1 sprig fresh rosemary

For the broccoli

  • 1 head broccoli
  • Salt
  • Pepper (optional)
  • Optional garnishes: grated Parmesan, lemon juice, Aleppo chili flakes, chopped parsley

Equipment

  • Vacuum sealer and bag
  • Sous‑vide circulator and water bath
  • Small saucepan for making infused oil
  • Trivet or heatproof pad

Method

  1. Optional: Make garlic‑rosemary oil – Put olive oil and garlic cloves into a small saucepan. Heat over medium‑high, basting the cloves until browned and roasty (about 10–12 minutes). Add rosemary. Transfer to a small bowl and let cool for about 15 minutes.
  2. Prep broccoli – Trim off the very end of the stem. Cut the head in half lengthwise, then cut each half into quarters to make long spears.
  3. Bag & season – Arrange spears in a single layer in a vacuum bag. Season with salt (and pepper, if using). If using the garlic‑rosemary oil, add some cloves and oil to the bag; if not, drizzle in a little olive oil. Seal.
  4. Protect – Set your water bath on a trivet or heatproof pad.
  5. Cook – Heat water to 90 °C. Submerge the bag and cook for 20 minutes. Ensure the broccoli stays under water; weigh down the bag if necessary.
  6. Serve – Remove spears and garnish as desired with Parmesan, lemon juice, chili flakes or parsley.

Ingredients

For the infused oil (optional)

  • About 0.25 cup (60 ml) olive oil
  • 3–4 garlic cloves, peeled
  • 1 sprig fresh rosemary (optional)

For the potatoes

  • 12 fingerling potatoes, washed
  • Salt
  • Pepper, for serving (optional)
  • Crème fraîche, for dipping (optional)

Equipment

  • Vacuum sealer and bag
  • Sous‑vide circulator and water bath
  • Small saucepan (if making infused oil)
  • Trivet or heatproof pad

Method

  1. Optional: Make infused oil – Combine olive oil and garlic in a pot over medium‑high heat. Cook, basting the garlic occasionally, until browned (about 10–12 minutes). Add rosemary and transfer to a bowl; cool for 15 minutes.
  2. Prep potatoes – Rinse fingerling potatoes. Plan on about six per person.
  3. Bag & season – Place potatoes in a single layer in the bag. Add salt and the cooled garlic cloves, rosemary and infused oil. If not making the oil, drizzle in plain olive oil instead.
  4. Seal – Vacuum seal.
  5. Protect – Place the pot on a trivet to protect your countertop.
  6. Cook – Preheat the bath to 90 °C. Submerge the bag completely and cook for 1 hour. Weight down the bag if it floats.
  7. Serve – Remove potatoes and serve whole or sliced. Optionally garnish with pepper and dip in crème fraîche thinned with a little of the infused oil. They’re also great pan‑fried for crispiness or used in potato salad.

Description: Yukon Golds have thin, creamy skins and a buttery flavour. Sous‑vide cooking followed by a quick sear or smash yields tender, flavour‑packed potatoes that pair well with meats or fish.

Tags: Beginner-friendly · Weeknight-friendly · Low effort · Great for leftovers

Ingredients

For the infused oil (optional)

  • 3–4 cloves garlic, peeled
  • About 0.25 cup (60 ml) olive oil
  • 1 sprig fresh rosemary (optional)

For the potatoes

  • 4 large Yukon Gold potatoes
  • Salt
  • Pepper, for serving (optional)
  • Chives, finely sliced, for garnish (optional)
  • Fresh dill, finely chopped, for garnish (optional)
  • Aioli or crème fraîche, for dunking (optional)

Equipment

  • Vacuum sealer and bag
  • Sous‑vide circulator and water bath
  • Trivet or heatproof pad
  • Skillet for optional pan‑fry or smash

Method

  1. Optional: Make infused oil – Cook garlic in olive oil over medium‑high heat until golden (10–12 minutes). Add rosemary and let cool for 15 minutes.
  2. Prep potatoes – Rinse Yukon Golds and trim any blemishes. Cut into ½ inch (1.3 cm) “half‑moon” wedges.
  3. Bag & season – Arrange potato wedges in a single layer in the bag. Season liberally with salt. Add cooled garlic cloves, rosemary and a splash of the garlic oil (or plain olive oil if not using the infusion). Seal.
  4. Cook – Preheat the bath to 90 °C. Submerge the bag and cook for 1 hour. Clip to the side and weight down if needed.
  5. Serve or crisp – Serve as is, garnished with chives or dill and accompanied by aioli for dipping. For extra texture, pan‑fry briefly or smash and roast before serving.

title: What is a kamado grill?
content:
A kamado is a thick, ceramic charcoal grill that holds heat and moisture extremely well. It can:

  • Smoke low & slow (pulled pork, ribs, brisket)
  • Roast (whole chicken, roasts, vegetables)
  • Grill at high heat (steaks, burgers, skewers)
  • Bake (pizza, bread, flatbreads)

Key parts:

  • Firebox – where the lump charcoal sits
  • Charcoal grate – at the bottom of the firebox
  • Heat deflector / platesetter – creates indirect heat for smoking and roasting
  • Cooking grate – where the food goes
  • Bottom vent – main air intake
  • Top vent – fine control of airflow and temperature

content:
• Direct heat – food sits directly above the charcoal; best for searing and quick cooks.
  • Indirect heat – heat deflectors in place, food not directly above the fire; best for most smoking recipes.

title: Lighting and stabilizing the kamado
content:
1. Fill the firebox

  • Use lump charcoal, not briquettes.
  • Long cooks (8–12 h): firebox at least ¾ full.
  • Short cooks (1–3 h): ½–¾ full is usually enough.

2. Light the charcoal

  • Open bottom vent fully and top vent fully.
  • Light in 1–2 spots on top.
  • Let the fire catch with lid open for a few minutes.

3. Close the lid and approach target slowly

  • Close lid with vents still open.
  • As dome approaches target, start closing vents:
  • Bottom: small opening for low & slow (often 1–2 cm).
  • Top: mostly closed, small gap.
  • Wait 5–10 minutes after each adjustment before changing again.
Heat momentum as you approach target temperature

The ceramic body and metal parts of a kamado store heat. Once they are warm, the grill has heat momentum: even if you start closing the vents, the dome temperature will usually keep climbing for a while before it flattens out or slowly drops.

As a simple rule of thumb:

  • For low & slow cooks around 110–130 °C (230–265 °F), start dialing the vents back when the dome is around

80–90 °C (175–195 °F).

  • For roasting around 160–190 °C (320–375 °F), start closing down more when the dome is about

20–30 °C (35–55 °F) below your target.

Make small changes to the bottom vent (a few millimeters at a time) and give the grill 5–10 minutes to respond before adjusting again. If you overshoot a little, slightly close the vents further and let the temperature drift back down instead of chasing it with big, fast corrections.

4. Stabilize before adding food

  • Keep dome in target range for 10–15 minutes.
  • Add food only when temperature is stable and smoke is clean.
Hand check for a stable dome (optional)

As an extra check before adding food, once the dome thermometer has sat in your target range for 10–15 minutes:

  • Put on a heat-resistant glove.
  • Briefly hold the back of your hand 10–15 cm above the top vent.
  • You should feel a steady, consistent stream of heat each time you check.
  • If each check feels noticeably hotter than the last, or the heat seems to surge up and down while the dome temperature

is still climbing, the grill is still coming up to temperature.

Combine this quick feel test with the thermometer and the look of the smoke. When all three are steady, the kamado is heat-soaked and ready for food.

content:
• Clean smoke: thin, almost invisible or light blue, pleasant smell.

  • Wait a few minutes with slightly more open vents, or
  • Briefly open lid for more air, then close and let settle.

title: Carryover heat, wrapping & resting
content:
When you remove meat from the heat, it keeps cooking for a while as the hotter outer layers transfer heat toward the cooler center. This is called carryover cooking. For most grilled or smoked meats, the internal temperature can rise by about 2–5 °C (3–9 °F) during the rest, and even more for very large roasts.

What this means in practice:

  • For steaks, chops, small tenderloins finished with a sear, pull them from the indirect phase a few degrees below

your final target and let them rest while you get the fire screaming hot for searing.

  • For larger roasts and big barbecue cuts (brisket, chuck, pork shoulder), once they are probe-tender, take them off the pit

and let them rest well wrapped. The center will usually climb a little before slowly cooling.

How to wrap and rest

For long cooks and large cuts:

  • Wrap tightly in unwaxed butcher paper or heavy-duty foil once the bark is where you want it.
  • Place the wrapped meat in a small dry cooler or an insulated bag lined with towels.
  • Rest at least 1 hour, and up to 2–3 hours for big roasts like brisket or pork shoulder.
  • Keep the meat above a safe serving temperature; if you plan to hold for many hours, treat it like a proper hot hold.

For medium cuts (pork loin, beef tri-tip, small roasts):

  • Rest 20–45 minutes loosely tented in foil on a board or tray.
  • If you plan to sear after the rest, pull these cuts a few degrees before target (see table below) and expect them to climb

a bit during the rest and sear.

For smaller pieces (thighs, wings, sausages, small fish fillets):

  • Rest 5–10 minutes on a warm plate or board, loosely tented if you like.
  • Focus on not overcooking them in the first place; carryover is smaller, but it still exists.

The goal of resting is twofold:

1. Let internal temperature stabilize without overshooting your target.

2. Give the meat a more even temperature from edge to center before slicing or pulling.

content:

Classic pulled pork shoulder cooked low and slow to shreddable tenderness with a deep bark.

Time & temperature

CutPit temperatureTimeInternal target
2–3 kg bone-in shoulder110–120 °C (230–250 °F)8–12 h88–95 °C (190–203 °F)

Setup

  • Indirect, deflectors in place
  • Firebox ¾ full of lump charcoal
  • 2–3 chunks apple or cherry wood (optionally with a little hickory)
  • Drip pan under the meat

Ingredients

  • 1 pork shoulder (2–3 kg), bone-in if possible
  • 30–60 g Sweet Pork Shoulder Rub or All-Purpose BBQ Rub
  • 15–30 ml (1–2 tbsp) yellow mustard or neutral oil as binder (optional)
  • 100–150 ml apple juice, cider, or broth for wrapping (optional)

Method

  1. Trim and prep – Trim away loose flaps of fat or skin. Leave a thin, even fat layer if present.
  2. Season – Lightly coat the surface with mustard or oil. Apply rub generously (20–30 g per kg) and press to adhere.
  3. Heat the grill – Set up for indirect cooking at 110–120 °C (230–250 °F). Add wood chunks and wait for clean smoke.
  4. Smoke unwrapped – Place the shoulder on the grate over the drip pan. Smoke until bark is set and internal temperature

is around 70–75 °C (158–167 °F), usually 4–6 hours.

  1. Wrap – Wrap tightly in heavy foil or unwaxed butcher paper with a small splash of apple juice or broth.
  2. Cook to tender – Return to the grill and cook until the internal temperature is 88–95 °C (190–203 °F) and a probe

slides in with little resistance.

  1. Rest – Rest wrapped in a warm cooler or warm spot for at least 1 hour (up to 2–3 hours).
  2. Pull and serve – Unwrap, reserve juices, and pull the meat with forks or gloved hands. Mix with its juices and adjust

seasoning with more rub or a little vinegar/BBQ sauce if desired.

content:
Difficulty: Medium Active time: 30–40 minutes Total time: 4½–6 hours Tags: Weekend project · Guests

Tender smoked pork ribs with bark and an optional sweet glaze.

Time & temperature

CutPit temperatureTimeInternal guide
St. Louis or baby back ribs110–120 °C (230–250 °F)4½–6 h88–95 °C (190–203 °F) + feel

Ingredients

  • 2 racks pork ribs (St. Louis or baby back)
  • 30–50 g Sweet Pork Shoulder Rub or All-Purpose BBQ Rub
  • 15–30 ml (1–2 tbsp) mustard or oil as binder

Optional for wrapping (mix and match):

  • 30–60 g brown sugar
  • 30–60 g butter
  • 30–60 ml honey or maple syrup
  • 60–120 ml apple juice

Optional glaze:

  • 120–240 ml BBQ sauce, thinned with a little water or juice

Method

  1. Prep ribs – Remove membrane from the bone side. Trim thin edges if needed.
  2. Season – Lightly coat ribs with mustard or oil. Apply rub on all sides.
  3. Smoke – Place ribs bone side down in an indirect setup at 110–120 °C (230–250 °F) with mild fruit wood.

Smoke 2½–3 hours until color deepens and rub has set.

  1. Wrap (optional) – Wrap each rack in foil or paper with a small amount of butter, sugar, and honey/maple plus a splash of juice.

Return to the grill for 1½–2 hours until very tender; meat should pull back from the bones.

  1. Glaze – Unwrap carefully. Brush lightly with sauce, if using, and return to the grill uncovered for 15–30 minutes

to set the glaze and tighten the bark.

  1. Rest and slice – Rest 10–15 minutes, then slice between bones and serve.

content:
Difficulty: Advanced Active time: 45–60 minutes Total time: 24–28 hours (mostly unattended) Tags: Weekend project · Hybrid Sous-Vide + Smoke · Great for leftovers

Sous-vide gives very consistent tenderness; the kamado adds bark and smoke.

Sous-vide stage

  • Temperature: 68 °C (154 °F)
  • Time: 24 hours

Smoke stage

  • Pit temperature: 110–120 °C (230–250 °F)
  • Time: 2–4 hours, or until bark and color look good

Ingredients

  • 1 brisket flat (1.5–2.5 kg)
  • 30–60 g Smoky Beef Rub (split between bag and post-sous-vide rub)
  • Optional: 30–60 ml (2–4 tbsp) beef tallow or a little beef stock in the bag

Method

  1. Season for sous-vide – Lightly season the brisket with 10–20 g of Smoky Beef Rub and a spoonful of tallow or a splash of stock.

Bag and seal.

  1. Cook sous-vide – Cook at 68 °C (154 °F) for 24 hours.
  2. Chill (recommended) – Cool in an ice bath for 20–30 minutes, then refrigerate until firm enough to handle easily.
  3. Preheat the kamado – Set up for indirect cooking at 110–120 °C (230–250 °F) with oak-based wood.
  4. Dry and re-season – Remove from the bag, reserving juices if desired. Pat completely dry and apply the remaining Smoky Beef Rub.
  5. Smoke – Place on the grill and smoke 2–4 hours, until bark is well formed and internal temperature is at least 70 °C (158 °F).
  6. Rest and slice – Rest 30–60 minutes, then slice against the grain.

content:

Sous-vide ribs ensure consistent tenderness; the kamado provides bark and optional glaze.

Sous-vide stage

  • Temperature: 74 °C (165 °F)
  • Time: 10–12 hours

Smoke stage

  • Pit temperature: 110–120 °C (230–250 °F)
  • Time: 1–2 hours

Ingredients

  • 2 racks pork ribs
  • 40–60 g Sweet Pork Shoulder Rub or All-Purpose BBQ Rub (split between bag and finishing)
  • Optional: small amount of BBQ sauce for glazing

Method

  1. Prep and season – Remove membrane and trim the ribs. Season lightly with rub (about half the total amount).
  2. Bag and cook sous-vide – Bag the ribs (single layer where possible) and cook at 74 °C (165 °F) for 10–12 hours.
  3. Chill – Chill in an ice bath 20–30 minutes, then refrigerate until firm. This makes handling easier.
  4. Preheat the kamado – Set for indirect cooking at 110–120 °C (230–250 °F) with mild fruit wood.
  5. Dry and re-season – Remove ribs from bags, pat dry, and apply remaining rub.
  6. Smoke – Smoke 1–2 hours until the surface is dry, slightly tacky, and nicely colored.
  7. Glaze (optional) – Brush lightly with sauce in the last 15–20 minutes.
  8. Rest and slice – Rest briefly, then slice between bones.

title: How much wood to use
content:
• Delicate foods (fish, shrimp, vegetables) – 1 small chunk (about golf-ball size) or a small handful of chips.
  • Medium cooks (chicken, pork tenderloin, small roasts) – 1–2 small chunks.
  • Long cooks (pork shoulder, ribs, brisket, chuck roast) – 2–3 small chunks mixed through the charcoal.

More wood does not always mean better flavor. Especially on small grills, too much wood can make food harsh or bitter.

title: Temperature swings up and down
content:
• Possible causes
    • Vents changed too often or in large steps
    • Lid opened frequently
    • Fire not fully stabilized before adding food
    • Very windy or very cold conditions
  • Fix
    • Make small vent changes, then wait 5–10 minutes.
    • Avoid opening the lid unless necessary; work quickly when you do.
  • Prevent
    • Stabilize at target temperature for 10–15 minutes before adding food.

title: Grill runs too hot and is hard to cool
content:
• Possible causes
    • Too much charcoal fully lit
    • Vents too far open
    • Lid left open too long during lighting
  • Fix
    • Close the top vent almost fully and narrow the bottom vent, then wait.
    • For very high temps, briefly close both almost fully to choke the fire, then reopen slightly.
  • Prevent
    • Light in 1–2 small spots instead of fully lighting the whole charcoal bed.
    • Close the lid earlier and let the temperature creep up to the target.

title: Grill cannot reach target temperature
content:
• Possible causes
    • Not enough charcoal in the firebox
    • Restricted airflow (ash blocking the grate, dirty vents)

    • Clear ash from the bottom grate.
    • Open vents further and wait for a response.
  • Prevent
    • For long cooks, fill the firebox at least ½–¾ full.
    • Clean out ash regularly.

title: Smoke is thick, white, or smells acrid
content:
• Possible causes
    • Fire not burning cleanly yet
    • Too much wood added at once
    • Damp wood or charcoal
  • Fix
    • Wait with the lid closed and vents slightly more open until smoke becomes thinner and smells pleasant.
    • If it stays harsh, briefly open the lid to give the fire more air, then close and let it settle.
  • Prevent
    • Add only 1–3 small chunks of wood for a junior-sized kamado.
    • Start cooking only once you have thin, blue or almost invisible smoke with a clean smell.

title: Food tastes bitter or overly smoky
content:
• Possible causes
    • Thick, dirty smoke for a long time
    • Too much wood, especially strong woods
    • Wet or green (unseasoned) wood
  • Fix
    • Let the smoke clean up before continuing; tent food loosely with foil if needed.
    • Serve with acidic sides (e.g., pickles, vinegar slaw, lemon wedges).
  • Prevent
    • Prefer mild woods and moderate amounts of stronger woods.
    • Err on the side of less wood; increase on the next cook if needed.

content:
• Possible causes
    • Very little wood used
    • Food added after most of the wood’s smoke has burned off

    • Add wood early in the cook, while the food is still cool and absorbing smoke.
    • For quick cooks (shrimp, wings, small tenderloins), ensure at least one chunk is actively smoking early on.

title: Meat is dry
content:
• Possible causes
    • Overcooking, especially lean cuts
    • Pit temperature too high for the cut
    • No rest or very short rest
    • Large cuts cooked unwrapped for too long after the stall
  • Fix
    • For pulled meats, shred and mix with juices, a little broth, or a light BBQ sauce.
    • Slice thinner and serve with moist sides.
  • Prevent
    • Use a thermometer and respect target internal temperatures.
    • Rest large cuts wrapped for at least 1 hour.
    • Keep lean cuts at the lower end of temperature ranges.

title: Chicken skin is rubbery
content:
• Possible causes
    • Pit temperature too low for too long
    • Skin too wet when going on the grill
    • Heavy, sugary sauces applied early

  • Prevent
    • Dry the skin well and ideally refrigerate uncovered for 30–90 minutes before cooking.
    • Apply sugary sauces late and in thin layers.

title: Fish breaks apart or is mushy
content:
• Possible causes
    • Overcooked fish
    • Cure too strong or too long
    • Rough handling when done
  • Fix
    • Serve as a spread, salad, or mixed into pasta rather than in slices.
  • Prevent
    • Use the shorter end of cure times and recommended cure amounts.
    • Pull fish at 57–60 °C (135–140 °F) and check earlier than you think.
    • Use a plank, tray, or wide spatula to move fish.

title: Fire starts to die during a long cook
content:
• Possible causes
    • Too little charcoal for the length of the cook
    • Ash blocking air holes or the charcoal grate
    • Very small pieces packed tightly, restricting airflow

    • Gently poke from the side to break up ash and improve airflow.
    • Open vents slightly and wait.
  • Prevent
    • For long cooks, fill the firebox ¾ full with a mix of larger and medium pieces.
    • Clean out ash before starting.

title: Flare-ups or grease fires
content:
• Possible causes
    • Fatty items cooked directly over the fire
    • Grease dripping onto very hot coals
    • Buildup of old grease in the grill
  • Fix
    • Move food to indirect heat or use a deflector and drip pan.
    • Close the lid and slightly close vents to reduce oxygen if a flare-up happens.
  • Prevent
    • For most smoking recipes, use an indirect setup with deflectors.
    • Place a drip pan under fatty cuts such as shoulder or whole chicken.
    • Periodically burn off or clean grease from grates and deflectors.

title: Food is ready too early
content:
• Fix
    • Large cuts (shoulder, brisket, chuck): wrap tightly and rest in a warm insulated cooler for 1–3 hours.
    • Smaller cuts: keep loosely covered in a warm oven for a shorter time.
  • Prevent
    • Plan with a buffer; most smoked meats improve with a longer rest.
